awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Advanced Salt Electrolysis Process for the Domestic Refinement of Battery Minerals
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of technologies that could perform high-efficiency salt splitting electrolysis more efficiently and at reduced cost via innovations in catalytic materials design and reactor architecture. Current state-of-the-art electrolysis technologies utilize potentially expensive catalytic materials and can have limited efficiency due to their unoptimized cell design. The electrolysis technology to be developed utilizes low-cost carbon-based flow-electrodes that have high-catalytic activity and incorporate the latest innovations from flow-battery cell design into electrochemical mineral refining. The result may be a reduction in cost and a reduction in the environmental impact of what is traditionally a high-emissions chemical process.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of potentially novel process technology. This innovation is the electrified, single-step conversion of lithium extracted from natural brines. This technology could have distinct economic and environmental advantages over conventional hydrothermal/chemical conversion processes and may support upstream chemical processes by producing hydrochloride for sorbent regeneration. This electrolysis technology may allow for ion-selective, closed-loop recycling, and could offer cost savings in energy consumption and carbon emissions compared to existing refinement processes that require a consistent supply of reagents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Through the support of the NSF I-Corps program, Team Aepnus has made significant strides in developing an environmentally friendly technology aimed at revolutionizing waste management within the battery industry. Our project centered on a novel approach using electrolysis, specifically designed for the recovery of valuable chemicals from sodium sulfate waste brines, a byproduct of battery manufacturing processes.

 

Intellectual Merit: The heart of our innovation lies in an advanced salt-splitting electrolysis system equipped with proprietary low-cost electrodes. This technology is a departure from conventional methods, focusing on the economic recycling of chemical waste into useful chemicals. Our system demonstrates a significant reduction in overall energy consumption and carbon emissions compared to current practices. It represents a substantial leap forward in electrochemistry and sustainable resource management, contributing to the broader scientific understanding of how we can more efficiently recycle and reuse waste materials.

 

Broader Impacts: The implications of our work extend well beyond the laboratory. By targeting the recycling of sodium sulfate waste brines, our technology offers a path to mitigate the environmental impacts associated with battery production. This innovation supports a more sustainable, circular economy within the battery industry, reducing waste and the demand for raw materials. It also aligns with national objectives to enhance energy independence and security by minimizing reliance on reagent chemicals and offering a circular approach. The economic benefits are equally compelling, with the potential for cost savings for battery manufacturers and the creation of new green jobs and businesses.

 

Throughout the project, we have actively engaged with stakeholders across the battery production chain to refine our technology and ensure that it meets industry needs. This dialogue has been instrumental in identifying the most pressing challenges and opportunities for impact. As we move forward, we are focused on further developing our system, conducting additional feasibility studies, and exploring partnerships for pilot projects. Our commitment to transparency and open communication will continue as we prepare to share our findings and progress with the public and the scientific community.

 

Our journey with the NSF I-Corps program has been invaluable in helping us pivot our focus towards a pressing environmental and industrial challenge. As we look to the future, Team Aepnus is excited about the potential of our technology to transform waste into value, contributing to a more sustainable and circular battery industry.


Last Modified: 03/31/2024
Modified by: Ashok Gadgil
